availability.p: The text of the original document is in the public domain. Subject to certain exceptions, public domain works may be freely copied or used in the creation of derivative works without permission, or authorization, of the former copyright owners.

Permission to reproduce the graphic images of the original item has been granted by the owners of the original for this publication only.

note.p: Lightly revised draft of a poem titled "Sounds of the Winter Too." Under the title "Sounds of the Winter," the poem was one of four belonging to the "Old Age Echoes" cluster, first published in Lippincott's Magazine 47 (March 1891) and then reprinted in Good-bye My Fancy (1891). The writing on the verso (not in Whitman's hand) makes reference to Good-Bye My Fancy and to "Sounds of Winter," as well as to a "Putnam 1902 Edition." There is also a postmark dated 18 October 1889.

bibl.author: Whitman, Walt
bibl.title: Old Age Echoes
bibl.idno: Rare Book Division; NYPL Catalog ID (B-number): b12414503; MSS Unit ID: 1767
bibl.orgName: The Oscar Lion Papers, New York Public Library, New York, N.Y.
bibl.note: Transcribed from digital images of the original.

The writing on the verso (not in Whitman's hand) makes reference to Good-Bye My Fancy and to "Sounds of Winter," as well as to a "Putnam 1902 Edition." There is also a postmark dated 18 October 1889, and a reference to Camden, New Jersey, that could be in Whitman's hand. The verso clearly displays the three separate pieces of paper that Whitman combined to draft "Old Age Echoes."

lg.head: Old age echoes
Sounds of the Winter too.
lg.l:
Sunshine upon the mountains—many a
distant strain

From cheery rail-road train‸—from nearer
field, barn, house,

The whisper'ding air—even the mute crops,
garner'd apples, corn,

Childrens' and womens' homes—the rhythm of
farmer and of flail,

The old man's gay and garrulous
lips among the rest. Think not
we yet give out yet.

Out ofForth from the snowy hairs we too
keep onup the lilt.
